title: Abhijit Banerjee Wins Nobel Prize In Economics, Phones Ring In Kashmir + More Top News
text:
The 2019 Nobel Prize for Economics was on October 14 awarded to Abhijit Banerjee, Esther Duflo and Michael Kremer for their experimental approach to alleviating global poverty."

"The research conducted by this year's Laureates has considerably improved our ability to fight global poverty. In just two decades, their new experiment-based approach has transformed development economics, which is now a flourishing field of research," said the Nobel committee in a statement.

In another tweet, The Nobel Prize Twitter handle said: “In the mid-1990s, Economic Sciences Laureate Michael Kremer and his colleagues demonstrated how powerful an experiment-based approach can be, using field experiments to test a range of interventions that could improve school results in western Kenya.” Read More

72 Days On, Postpaid Mobile Services Restored In Kashmir But No Internet Yet

Postpaid mobile phone networks were restored in the Kashmir valley on October 14 after a 72-day blackout but the internet remains off-limits to the region's seven million-plus people.

Don't Miss 290 SHARES 802 SHARES 484 SHARES

Access to mobile networks in the Kashmir Valley were snapped in early August citing security concerns as the controversial Article 370 of the Indian Constitution that granted special status to the state of Jammu and Kashmir was partially scrapped by the Indian parliament .

The easing on Monday covers around four million post-paid mobile phone contracts, but only for calls and text messages. The internet is still unavailable on both cellphones and fixed line networks. Read More

Close To 15 Lakh People In Delhi Got Zero Electricity Bills In September Under Zero Subsidy Plan

In what could prove to be game changer for the ruling Aam Aadmi Party in the national capital, more than 14.64 lakh households paid a zero charge for the electricity bills issued in September, under Delhi government’s first month of free electricity scheme.

Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal, in August, announced free electricity scheme ‘Mukhyamantri Kirayedar Bijli Meter Yojna’, of up to 200 units, for domestic consumers, and later extended the scheme to tenants living in the national capital.

Per the data provided by the power department, as many as 28 per cent of the total 52.27 lakh domestic consumers in the city paid Rs Zero towards their electricity bills, for consuming power in the month of September. Read More

5,700 Mature Trees Won’t Be Cut, Instead Transplanted Elsewhere To Build Dwarka Expressway

In what could pave way for better management of trees for development purposes, 5,700 fully grown trees will be transplanted elsewhere to build the Dwarka Expressway, providing another link to Gurgaon.

This perhaps is the biggest transplantation drive in the country.

The National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) has close to three to four months to finish the job and while officials say they are on the job, they insist that an extension in time is required in order to save maximum trees. Read More

Pranjil Patil becomes India’s first visually-challenged woman IAS officer

The Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) is regarded among the toughest examinations to crack and hundreds of thousands of aspirants flock coaching centres in major metropolitan cities across the country in the hope to join the IAS, IPS and IFS ranks.

And the journey was more tedious for Pranjil Patil, who has become the country’s first visually-challenged woman IAS officer.

"Never be defeated, Never give up,'' she said as she assumed charge as the Sub Collector of Thiruvananthapuram, the capital of Kerala, on October 14. Read More

Postpaid mobile phone networks were restored in the Kashmir valley on October 14 after a 72-day blackout but the internet remains off-limits to the region's seven million-plus people.
